currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always yound men.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

But teh question here, is whether, given t allowing extreme sports

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, whould society cons allowing extreme sports

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, whould society consone risk-taking by young males  allowing extreme sports

It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone srisk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed s

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a mor

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an elment of risk, here is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an elment of risk, and injuries are common.here is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an elment of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few mmen hahere is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.

It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an elment of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few mmen have even died as a resulhere is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an elment of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few mmen have even died as a result of sports injuries, lhere is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an element of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few men have even died as a result of sports injuries. here is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an element of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few men have even died as a result of sports injuries. here is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.
 Perhaps those who participate in extreme sports are pushing that point. But the imprtant fact is that young men will co

It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an element of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few men have even died as a result of sports injuries. here is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.
 Perhaps those who participate in extreme sports are pushing that point. But the imprtant fact is that young men will court the same level of risk

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an element of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few men have even died as a result of sports injuries. here is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.
 Perhaps those who participate in extreme sports are pushing that point. But the imprtant fact is that young men will court the same level of risk whether people will pay t

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

But the important fact is that young men will court the same level of risk whether people will pay to watch or not. It is their nature. So we who watch extreme sports do not really alter the equation, we just enjoy what they do.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an element of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few men have even died as a result of sports injuries. here is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.
 Perhaps those who participate in extreme sports may indeed be pushing that point, but the important fact is that young men will court the same level of risk whether people will pay to watch or not. It is their nature. So we who watch extreme sports do not really alter the equation, we just enjoy what they do.

The fact is, men are big enough to choose for themselves whether they take on risk.

 Perhaps those who participate in extreme sports may indeed be pushing that point, but the important fact is that young men will court the same level of risk whether people will pay to watch or not. It is their nature. So we who watch extreme sports do not really alter the equation, we just enjoy what they do.

he fact is, men acanchoose for themselves whether they take on risk.

he fact is, men acanchoose for themselves whether they take on risk.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.

 Perhaps those who participate in extreme sports may indeed be pushing that point, but the important fact is that young men will court the same level of risk whether people will pay to watch or not. It is their nature. So we who watch extreme sports do not really alter the equation, we just enjoy what they do.

he fact is, men acanchoose for themselves whether they take on risk.

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an element of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few men have even died as a result of sports injuries. here is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.
 Perhaps those who participate in extreme sports may indeed be pushing that point, but the important fact is that young men will court the same level of risk whether people will pay to watch or not. It is their nature. So we who watch extreme sports do not really alter the equation, we just enjoy what they do.

he fact is, men acanchoose for themselves whether they take on risk.
 And spectators can choose for themselves whether to watch it. There may be moral issues here, b

It is their nature. So we who watch extreme sports do not really alter the equation, we just enjoy what they do.

he fact is, men acanchoose for themselves whether they take on risk.
 And spectators can choose for themselves whether to watch it. There may be moral issues here, but none of them align

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.

It is their nature. So we who watch extreme sports do not really alter the equation, we just enjoy what they do.

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an element of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few men have even died as a result of sports injuries. here is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.
 Perhaps those who participate in extreme sports may indeed be pushing that point, but the important fact is that young men will court the same level of risk whether people will pay to watch or not. It is their nature. So we who watch extreme sports do not really alter the equation, we just enjoy what they do.

he fact is, men acanchoose for themselves whether they take on risk.
 And spectators can choose for themselves whether to watch it. There may be moral issues here, but none of them align with the differences

 Perhaps those who participate in extreme sports may indeed be pushing that point, but the important fact is that young men will court the same level of risk whether people will pay to watch or not. It is their nature. So we who watch extreme sports do not really alter the equation, we just enjoy what they do.

he fact is, men acanchoose for themselves whether they take on risk.

Young men generally take risks. The reasons for this are unclear. Some argue that the human brain is not fully formed until the late twenties. What ever the reason, soldiers who willingly risk death are almost always young men. The same is true for extreme mountain climbers.
It is a well-known fact that the majority of deaths among professional rock climbers occur in the twenties, the prime of their lives.

It is generally thought that men crave risk, even foolishly so, while women acknowledge risks much more realistically.
 Although that may be an oversimplification, there is clearly an underlying difference between the way men and women deal with risk.

Given these facts, would society condone risk-taking by young males by allowing extreme sports. The fact is, society already condone risk-taking by young males by recruiting them for the armed services. So there is less of a moral issue here than one might at first think.
TAll sports have an element of risk, and injuries are common. More than a few men have even died as a result of sports injuries. here is a point, however, where the sheer level of risk involved begins to feel too high.
 Perhaps those who participate in extreme sports may indeed be pushing that point, but the important fact is that young men will court the same level of risk whether people will pay to watch or not. It is their nature. So we who watch extreme sports do not really alter the equation, we just enjoy what they do.

he fact is, men acanchoose for themselves whether they take on risk.
 And spectators can choose for themselves whether to watch it. There may be moral issues here, but none of them align with the differences between extreme sports and other activities.
What Do You Think?? Let me kn@twitter_handle.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not?
